1:
I have made a covenant with my eyes;\q how then should I look with desire on a virgin?
\q
2:
For what is the portion from God above,\q the inheritance from the Almighty on high?


\q
3:
I used to think that calamity is for unrighteous people,\q and that disaster is for doers of wickedness.
\q
4:
Does not God see my ways\q and count all my steps?
\m


\q
5:
If I have walked with falsehood,\q if my foot has hurried to deceit,
\q
6:
let me be weighed in an even balance\q so that God will know my integrity.


\q
7:
If my step has turned aside from the way,\q if my heart has gone after my eyes,
\q if any spot has stuck to my hands,
\q
8:
then let me sow, and let another eat,\q and let my crops be uprooted.
\m


\q
9:
If my heart has been deceived by a woman,\q if I have lain in wait at my neighbor's door,
\q
10:
then let my wife grind grain for another,\q and let others bow down on her.


\q
11:
For that would be a terrible crime;\q indeed, it would be a crime to be punished by judges.
\q
12:
For that is a fire that consumes everything for Sheol\q and that would burn up all my harvest.


\q
13:
If I ignored the plea for justice from my male or female servant\q when they argued with me,
\q
14:
what then would I do when God rises up to accuse me?\q When he comes to judge me, how would I answer him?
\q
15:
Did the one who made me in the womb not make them also?\q Did not the same one mold us all in the womb?
\m


\q
16:
If I have withheld poor people from their desire,\q or if I have caused the eyes of the widow to grow dim from crying,
\q
17:
or if I have eaten my morsel alone\q and not allowed those without fathers to eat it also—
\q
18:
because from my youth the orphan grew up with me as with a father,\q and I have guided his mother, a widow, from my own mother's womb.
 

\q
19:
If I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing,\q or if I have seen that a needy man had no clothing;
\q
20:
if his heart has not blessed me\q because he has not been warmed with the wool of my sheep,
\q
22:
If I have done these things, then let my shoulder fall from the shoulder blade,\q and let my arm be broken from its joint.
\q
23:
For I dreaded destruction from God;\q because of his majesty, I was not able to do those things.
\m


\q
24:
If I have made gold my hope,\q and if I have said to fine gold, 'You are what I am confident in';
\q
26:
If I have seen the sun when it shone,\q or the moon walking in its brightness,
\q
27:
and if my heart has been secretly attracted,\q so that my mouth has kissed my hand in worship of them—
\q
28:
this also would be a crime to be punished by judges,\q for I would have denied the God who is above.


\q
29:
If I have rejoiced at the destruction of anyone who hated me\q or congratulated myself when disaster overtook him,
\q then bring charges against me!
\q
30:
Indeed, I have not even allowed my mouth to sin\q by asking for his life with a curse.


\q
31:
If the men of my tent have never said,\q 'Who can find one who has not been filled with Job's food?'
\q
32:
(even the foreigner has never had to stay in the city square,\q because I have always opened my doors to the traveler), 
\q and if that is not so, then bring charges against me!


\q
33:
If, like mankind, I have hidden my sins\q by hiding my guilt inside my tunic
\q
34:
(because I feared the great multitude,\q because the contempt of families terrified me,
\q so that I kept silent and would not go outside),
\q then bring charges against me!


\q
35:
Oh, if only I had someone to hear me!\q See, here is my signature; let the Almighty answer me!
\q If only I had the indictment that my opponent has written!
\q
36:
Surely I would carry it openly on my shoulder;\q I would put it on like a crown.
\q
37:
I would declare to him an accounting for my steps;\q as a confident prince I would go up to him.


\q
38:
If my land ever cries out against me,\q and its furrows weep together,
\q
39:
if I have eaten its harvest without paying for it\q or have caused its owners to lose their lives,
\q
40:
then let thorns grow instead of wheat\q and weeds instead of barley."
\m
 The words of Job are finished.
